The main functions treated in this chapter are the parabolic cylinder functions (PCFs), also known as Weber parabolic cylinder functions: U\left(a,z\right) , V\left(a,z\right) , \overline{U}\left(a,z\right) , and W\left(a,z\right).
These notations are due to ( , 1955) .
An older notation, due to ( ) , for U\left(a,z\right) is D_{\nu}\left(z\right).
The notations are related by U\left(a,z\right)=D_{-a-\frac{1}{2}}\left(z\right).
Whittaker’s notation D_{\nu}\left(z\right) is useful when \nu is a nonnegative integer (Hermite polynomial case).

PCFs are solutions of the differential equation \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+\left(az^{2}+bz+c\right)w=0, with three distinct standard forms \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}-\left(\tfrac{1}{4}z^{2}+a\right)w=0, \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+\left(\tfrac{1}{4}z^{2}-a\right)w=0, \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+\left(\nu+\tfrac{1}{2}-\tfrac{1}{4 }z^{2}\right)w=0.
Each of these equations is transformable into the others.
All solutions are entire functions of z and entire functions of a or \nu.

For real values of z (=x) , numerically satisfactory pairs of solutions (§LABEL:sec:AS.DE.NSS) of (LABEL:eq:PC.DE.D2) are U\left(a,x\right) and V\left(a,x\right) when x is positive, or U\left(a,-x\right) and V\left(a,-x\right) when x is negative.
For (LABEL:eq:PC.DE.D3) W\left(a,x\right) and W\left(a,-x\right) comprise a numericallysatisfactory pair, for all x\in\mathbb{R}.
The solutions W\left(a,\pm x\right) are treated in §LABEL:sec:PC.EW.

In \mathbb{C} , for j=0,1,2,3 , U\left((-1)^{j-1}a,(-i)^{j-1}z\right) and U\left((-1)^{j}a,(-i)^{j}z\right) comprise a numerically satisfactory pair of solutions in the half-plane \tfrac{1}{4}(2j-3)\pi\leq\operatorname{ph}z\leq\tfrac{1}{4}(2j+1)\pi.

section.title: Uniform Asymptotic Expansions for Large Parameter

para.sentence: In this section we give asymptotic expansions of PCFs for large values of the parameter a that are uniform with respect to the variable z , when both a and z (=x) are real.
These expansions follow from ( ) , where detailed information is also given for complex variables.
With the transformations a=\pm\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2}, x=\mu t\sqrt{2}, (LABEL:eq:PC.DE.D2) becomes \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}t}^{2}}=\mu^{4}(t^{2}\pm 1)w.
With the upper sign in (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.U2), expansions can be constructed for large \mu in terms of elementary functions that are uniform for t\in(-\infty,\infty) (§LABEL:sec:AS.DEWP.CI).
With the lower sign there are turning points at t=\pm 1 , which need to be excluded from the regions of validity.
These cases are treated in §§LABEL:sec:PC.UA.L2–LABEL:sec:PC.UA.L6.
The turning points can be included if expansions in terms of Airy functions are used instead of elementary functions (§LABEL:sec:AS.DEWP.CII).
These cases are treated in §§LABEL:sec:PC.UA.L7–LABEL:sec:PC.UA.L8.
Throughout this section the symbol \delta again denotes an arbitrary small positive constant.

The coefficients are given by {\cal A}_{s}(t)=\frac{u_{s}(t)}{(t^{2}-1)^{\frac{3}{2}s}},~{}{\cal B}_{s}(t)= \frac{v_{s}(t)}{(t^{2}-1)^{\frac{3}{2}s}}, where u_{s}(t) and v_{s}(t) are polynomials in t of degree 3s , ( s odd), 3s-2 ( s even, s\geq 2 ).

Higher polynomials u_{s}(t) can be calculated from the recurrence relation (t^{2}-1)u^{\prime}_{s}(t)-3stu_{s}(t)=r_{s-1}(t), where 8r_{s}(t)=(3t^{2}+2)u_{s}(t)-12(s+1)tr_{s-1}(t)+4(t^{2}-1)r^{\prime}_{s-1}(t), and the v_{s}(t) then follow from v_{s}(t)=u_{s}(t)+\tfrac{1}{2}tu_{s-1}(t)-r_{s-2}(t).

Lastly, the function g(\mu) in (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.U3) and (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.U4) has the asymptotic expansion: g(\mu)\sim h(\mu)\left(1+\frac{1}{2}\sum_{s=1}^{\infty}\frac{\gamma_{s}}{( \frac{1}{2}\mu^{2})^{s}}\right), where h(\mu)=2^{-\frac{1}{4}\mu^{2}-\frac{1}{4}}e^{-\frac{1}{4}\mu^{2}}\mu^{\frac{1} {2}\mu^{2}-\frac{1}{2}}, and the coefficients \gamma_{s} are defined by \Gamma\left(\tfrac{1}{2}+z\right)\sim\sqrt{2\pi}e^{-z}z^{z}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty} \frac{\gamma_{s}}{z^{s}}; compare (LABEL:eq:GA.AE.PE.6).

When \mu\to\infty , asymptotic expansions for the functions U\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},-\mu t\sqrt{2}\right) and V\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},-\mu t\sqrt{2}\right) that are uniform for t\in[1+\delta,\infty) are obtainable by substitution into (LABEL:eq:PC.RF.11) and (LABEL:eq:PC.RF.12) by means of (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.U3) and (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.95).
Similarly for U'\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},-\mu t\sqrt{2}\right) and V'\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},-\mu t\sqrt{2}\right).
As a\to-\infty

U\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},\mu t\sqrt{2}\right)\sim\frac{2g(\mu)}{(1-t^{2})^{ \frac{1}{4}}}\*\left(\cos\kappa\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{s}\frac{\widetilde{ \cal{A}}_{2s}(t)}{\mu^{4s}}-\sin\kappa\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{s}\frac{ \widetilde{\cal{A}}_{2s+1}(t)}{\mu^{4s+2}}\right), , U'\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},\mu t\sqrt{2}\right)\sim\mu\sqrt{2}g(\mu)(1-t^{2} )^{\frac{1}{4}}\*\left(\sin\kappa\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{s}\frac{\widetilde{ \cal{B}}_{2s}(t)}{\mu^{4s}}+\cos\kappa\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{s}\frac{ \widetilde{\cal{B}}_{2s+1}(t)}{\mu^{4s+2}}\right), , V\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},\mu t\sqrt{2}\right)\sim\frac{2g(\mu)}{\Gamma\left (\tfrac{1}{2}+\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2}\right)(1-t^{2})^{\frac{1}{4}}}\*\left(\cos \chi\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{s}\frac{\widetilde{\cal{A}}_{2s}(t)}{\mu^{4s}}- \sin\chi\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{s}\frac{\widetilde{\cal{A}}_{2s+1}(t)}{\mu^{4 s+2}}\right), , V'\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},\mu t\sqrt{2}\right)\sim\frac{\mu\sqrt{2}g(\mu)(1 -t^{2})^{\frac{1}{4}}}{\Gamma\left(\tfrac{1}{2}+\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2}\right)}\* \left(\sin\chi\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{s}\frac{\widetilde{\cal{B}}_{2s}(t)}{ \mu^{4s}}+\cos\chi\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{s}\frac{\widetilde{\cal{B}}_{2s+1}( t)}{\mu^{4s+2}}\right),
uniformly for t\in[-1+\delta,1-\delta].

The quantities \kappa and \chi are defined by \kappa=\mu^{2}\eta-\tfrac{1}{4}\pi, \chi=\mu^{2}\eta+\tfrac{1}{4}\pi, where \eta=\tfrac{1}{2}\operatorname{arccos}t-\tfrac{1}{2}t\sqrt{1-t^{2}}, and the coefficients \widetilde{\cal{A}}_{s}(t) and \widetilde{\cal{B}}_{s}(t) are given by \widetilde{\cal{A}}_{s}(t)=\frac{u_{s}(t)}{(1-t^{2})^{\frac{3}{2}s}}, \widetilde{\cal{B}}_{s}(t)=\frac{v_{s}(t)}{(1-t^{2})^{\frac{3}{2}s}}; compare (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.U6).

As a\to\infty U\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},\mu t\sqrt{2}\right)\sim\frac{\overline{g}(\mu)e^{- \mu^{2}{\overline{\xi}}}}{(t^{2}+1)^{\frac{1}{4}}}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{ \overline{u}_{s}(t)}{(t^{2}+1)^{\frac{3}{2}s}}\frac{1}{\mu^{2s}}, uniformly for t\in\mathbb{R}.

Here bars do not denote complex conjugates; instead \overline{\xi}=\tfrac{1}{2}t\sqrt{t^{2}+1}+\tfrac{1}{2}\ln\left(t+\sqrt{t^{2}+ 1}\right), \overline{u}_{s}(t)=i^{s}u_{s}(-it), and the function \overline{g}(\mu) has the asymptotic expansion \overline{g}(\mu)\sim\frac{1}{\mu\sqrt{2}h(\mu)}\left(1+\frac{1}{2}\sum_{s=1}^ {\infty}(-1)^{s}\frac{\gamma_{s}}{(\frac{1}{2}\mu^{2})^{s}}\right), where h(\mu) and \gamma_{s} are as in §LABEL:sec:PC.UA.L2.

With the same conditions U'\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},\mu t\sqrt{2}\right)\sim{-\frac{\mu}{\sqrt{2}} \overline{g}(\mu)(t^{2}+1)^{\frac{1}{4}}e^{-\mu^{2}{\overline{\xi}}}\sum_{s=0} ^{\infty}\frac{\overline{v}_{s}(t)}{(t^{2}+1)^{\frac{3}{2}s}}\frac{1}{\mu^{2s} }}, where \overline{v}_{s}(t)=i^{s}v_{s}(-it).

subsection.title: Modifications of Expansions in Elementary Functions

para.sentence: In ( ) modifications are given of Olver’s expansions.

An example is the following modification of (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.U3) U\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},\mu t\sqrt{2}\right)\sim\frac{h(\mu)e^{-\mu^{2}\xi }}{(t^{2}-1)^{\frac{1}{4}}}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{\mathsf{A}_{s}(\tau)}{\mu^ {2s}}, where \xi and h(\mu) are as in (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.U5) and (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.U14) , \tau=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{t}{\sqrt{t^{2}-1}}-1\right), and the coefficients \mathsf{A}_{s}(\tau) are the product of \tau^{s} and a polynomial in \tau of degree 2s.

They satisfy the recursion \mathsf{A}_{s+1}(\tau)=-4\tau^{2}(\tau+1)^{2}\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}\tau} \mathsf{A}_{s}(\tau)-\frac{1}{4}\int_{0}^{\tau}\left(20u^{2}+20u+3\right) \mathsf{A}_{s}(u)\mathrm{d}u, subject to s=0,1,2,\dots, starting with \mathsf{A}_{o}(\tau)=1.
The modified expansion (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.U31) shares the property of (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.U3) that it applies when \mu\to\infty uniformly with respect to t\in[1+\delta,\infty).
In addition, it enjoys a double asymptotic property: it holds if either or both \mu and t tend to infinity.
Observe that if t\to\infty , then \mathsf{A}_{s}(\tau)=O\left(t^{-2s}\right) , whereas {\cal A}_{s}(t)=O(1) or O\left(t^{-2}\right) according as s is even or odd.
The proof of the double asymptotic property then follows with the aid of error bounds; compare §LABEL:sec:BS.MAEO.DA.
For additional information see ( ) .
See also ( , pp. 206–208) and ( ) .

subsection.title: Negative a, -2\sqrt{-a}<x<\infty. Expansions in Terms of Airy Functions

para.sentence: The following expansions hold for large positive real values of \mu , uniformly for t\in[-1+\delta,\infty).
(For complex values of \mu and t see ( ) .)

U\left(-\frac{1}{2}\mu^{2},\mu t\sqrt{2}\right)\sim 2\pi^{\frac{1}{2}}\mu^{ \frac{1}{3}}g(\mu)\phi(\zeta)\*\left(\mathrm{Ai}\left(\mu^{\frac{4}{3}}\zeta \right)\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{A_{s}(\zeta)}{\mu^{4s}}+\frac{\mathrm{Ai}' \left(\mu^{\frac{4}{3}}\zeta\right)}{\mu^{\frac{8}{3}}}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty} \frac{B_{s}(\zeta)}{\mu^{4s}}\right), , U'\left(-\frac{1}{2}\mu^{2},\mu t\sqrt{2}\right)\sim\frac{(2\pi)^{\frac{1}{2}} \mu^{\frac{2}{3}}g(\mu)}{\phi(\zeta)}\*\left(\frac{\mathrm{Ai}\left(\mu^{\frac {4}{3}}\zeta\right)}{\mu^{\frac{4}{3}}}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{C_{s}(\zeta)}{ \mu^{4s}}+\mathrm{Ai}'\left(\mu^{\frac{4}{3}}\zeta\right)\sum_{s=0}^{\infty} \frac{D_{s}(\zeta)}{\mu^{4s}}\right), , V\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},\mu t\sqrt{2}\right)\sim\frac{2\pi^{\frac{1}{2}} \mu^{\frac{1}{3}}g(\mu)\phi(\zeta)}{\Gamma\left(\tfrac{1}{2}+\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{ 2}\right)}\*\left(\mathrm{Bi}\left(\mu^{\frac{4}{3}}\zeta\right)\sum_{s=0}^{ \infty}\frac{A_{s}(\zeta)}{\mu^{4s}}+\frac{\mathrm{Bi}'\left(\mu^{\frac{4}{3}} \zeta\right)}{\mu^{\frac{8}{3}}}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{B_{s}(\zeta)}{\mu^{4s }}\right), , V'\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},\mu t\sqrt{2}\right)\sim\frac{(2\pi)^{\frac{1}{2} }\mu^{\frac{2}{3}}g(\mu)}{\phi(\zeta)\Gamma\left(\tfrac{1}{2}+\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^ {2}\right)}\*\left(\frac{\mathrm{Bi}\left(\mu^{\frac{4}{3}}\zeta\right)}{\mu^{ \frac{4}{3}}}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{C_{s}(\zeta)}{\mu^{4s}}+\mathrm{Bi}' \left(\mu^{\frac{4}{3}}\zeta\right)\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{D_{s}(\zeta)}{\mu^ {4s}}\right).

The variable \zeta is defined by \tfrac{2}{3}\zeta^{\frac{3}{2}}=\xi,\quad\text{$1\leq t$},\text{($\zeta\geq 0$ )};, \tfrac{2}{3}(-\zeta)^{\frac{3}{2}}=\eta,\quad\text{$-1<t\leq 1$},\text{($\zeta \leq 0$)}, where \xi,\eta are given by (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.U5), (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.U24), respectively, and \phi(\zeta)=\left(\frac{\zeta}{t^{2}-1}\right)^{\frac{1}{4}}.
The function \zeta=\zeta(t) is real for t>-1 and analytic at t=1.

Inversely, with w=2^{-\frac{1}{3}}\zeta , t=1+w-\tfrac{1}{10}w^{2}+\tfrac{11}{350}w^{3}-\tfrac{823}{63000}w^{4}+\tfrac{1 \;50653}{242\;55000}w^{5}+\cdots, subject to |\zeta|<\left(\tfrac{3}{4}\pi\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}.
For g(\mu) see (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.U13).

The coefficients A_{s}(\zeta) and B_{s}(\zeta) are given by A_{s}(\zeta)=\zeta^{-3s}\sum_{m=0}^{2s}\beta_{m}(\phi(\zeta))^{6(2s-m)}u_{2s-m }(t), \zeta^{2}B_{s}(\zeta)=-\zeta^{-3s}\sum_{m=0}^{2s+1}\alpha_{m}(\phi(\zeta))^{6( 2s-m+1)}u_{2s-m+1}(t), where \phi(\zeta) is as in (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.A6), u_{k}(t) is as in §LABEL:sec:PC.UA.L2, \alpha_{0}=1 , and \alpha_{m}=\frac{(2m+1)(2m+3)\cdots(6m-1)}{m!(144)^{m}}, \beta_{m}=-\frac{6m+1}{6m-1}\alpha_{m}.

The coefficients C_{s}(\zeta) and D_{s}(\zeta) in (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.A2) and (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.A4) are given by C_{s}(\zeta)=\chi(\zeta)A_{s}(\zeta)+A^{\prime}_{s}(\zeta)+\zeta B_{s}(\zeta), D_{s}(\zeta)=A_{s}(\zeta)+\chi(\zeta)B_{s-1}(\zeta)+B^{\prime}_{s-1}(\zeta), where \chi(\zeta)=\frac{\phi^{\prime}(\zeta)}{\phi(\zeta)}=\frac{1-2t(\phi(\zeta))^{ 6}}{4\zeta}.

Explicitly, \zeta C_{s}(\zeta)=-\zeta^{-3s}\sum_{m=0}^{2s+1}\beta_{m}(\phi(\zeta))^{6(2s-m +1)}v_{2s-m+1}(t), D_{s}(\zeta)=\zeta^{-3s}\sum_{m=0}^{2s}\alpha_{m}(\phi(\zeta))^{6(2s-m)}v_{2s- m}(t), where v_{k}(t) is as in §LABEL:sec:PC.UA.L2.
The expansions (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.A1)–(LABEL:eq:PC.UA.A4) can be modified, again see ( ) , and the new expansions hold if either or both \mu and t tend to infinity.
This is provable by the methods used in §LABEL:sec:BS.MAEO.DAP.

subsection.title: Negative a, -\infty<x<2\sqrt{-a}. Expansions in Terms of Airy Functions

para.sentence: When \mu\to\infty , asymptotic expansions for U\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},-\mu t\sqrt{2}\right) and V\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},-\mu t\sqrt{2}\right) that are uniform for t\in[-1+\delta,\infty) are obtained by substitution into (LABEL:eq:PC.RF.11) and (LABEL:eq:PC.RF.12) by means of (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.A1) and (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.A3).
Similarly for U'\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},-\mu t\sqrt{2}\right) and V'\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},-\mu t\sqrt{2}\right).
If a\geq-\tfrac{1}{2} , then U\left(a,x\right) has no real zeros.
If -\tfrac{3}{2}<a<-\tfrac{1}{2} , then U\left(a,x\right) has no positive real zeros.
If -2n-\tfrac{3}{2}<a<-2n+\tfrac{1}{2} , n=1,2,\dots , then U\left(a,x\right) has n positive real zeros.
Lastly, when a=-n-\tfrac{1}{2} , n=1,2,\dots (Hermite polynomial case) U\left(a,x\right) has n zeros and they lie in the interval [-2\sqrt{-a},2\sqrt{-a}\,].
For further information on these cases see ( ) .
If a>-\tfrac{1}{2} , then V\left(a,x\right) has no positive real zeros, and if a=\tfrac{3}{2}-2n , n\in\mathbb{Z} , then V\left(a,x\right) has a zero at x=0.
When a>-\frac{1}{2} , U\left(a,z\right) has a string of complex zeros that approaches the ray \operatorname{ph}z=\frac{3}{4}\pi as z\to\infty , and a conjugate string.

When a>-\frac{1}{2} the zeros are asymptotically given by z_{a,s} and \overline{z_{a,s}} , where s is a large positive integer and z_{a,s}=e^{\frac{3}{4}\pi i}\sqrt{2\tau_{s}}\left(1-\frac{ia\lambda_{s}}{2\tau _{s}}+\frac{2a^{2}\lambda_{s}^{2}-8a^{2}\lambda_{s}+4a^{2}+3}{16\tau_{s}^{2}}+ O\left(\lambda_{s}^{3}\tau_{s}^{-3}\right)\right), with \tau_{s}=\left(2s+\tfrac{1}{2}-a\right)\pi+i\ln\left(\pi^{-\frac{1}{2}}2^{-a- \frac{1}{2}}\Gamma\left(\tfrac{1}{2}+a\right)\right), and \lambda_{s}=\ln\tau_{s}-\tfrac{1}{2}\pi i.
When a=\tfrac{1}{2} these zeros are the same as the zeros of the complementary error function \operatorname{erfc}(z/\sqrt{2}) ; compare (LABEL:eq:PC.SV.S5).
Numerical calculations in this case show that z_{\frac{1}{2},s} corresponds to the s th zero on the string; compare §LABEL:sec:ER.ZE.EC.

For large negative values of a the real zeros of U\left(a,x\right) , U'\left(a,x\right) , V\left(a,x\right) , and V'\left(a,x\right) can be approximated by reversion of the Airy-type asymptotic expansions of §§LABEL:sec:PC.UA.L7 and LABEL:sec:PC.UA.L8.

For example, let the s th real zeros of U\left(a,x\right) and U'\left(a,x\right) , counted in descending order away from the point z=2\sqrt{-a} , be denoted by u_{a,s} and u^{\prime}_{a,s} , respectively.

Then u_{a,s}\sim 2^{\frac{1}{2}}\mu\left(p_{0}(\alpha)+\frac{p_{1}(\alpha)}{\mu^{4} }+\frac{p_{2}(\alpha)}{\mu^{8}}+\cdots\right), as \mu ( =\sqrt{-2a} ) \to\infty , s fixed. Here \alpha=\mu^{-\frac{4}{3}}a_{s} , a_{s} denoting the s th negative zero of the function \mathrm{Ai} (see §LABEL:sec:AI.ZE.ID).

The first two coefficients are given by p_{0}(\zeta)=t(\zeta), where t(\zeta) is the function inverse to \zeta(t) , defined by (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.A5) (see also (LABEL:eq:PC.UA.A7)), and p_{1}(\zeta)=\frac{t^{3}-6t}{24(t^{2}-1)^{2}}+\frac{5}{48((t^{2}-1)\zeta^{3})^ {\frac{1}{2}}}.

Similarly, for the zeros of U'\left(a,x\right) we have u^{\prime}_{a,s}\sim 2^{\frac{1}{2}}\mu\left(q_{0}(\beta)+\frac{q_{1}(\beta)}{ \mu^{4}}+\frac{q_{2}(\beta)}{\mu^{8}}+\cdots\right), where \beta=\mu^{-\frac{4}{3}}a^{\prime}_{s} , a^{\prime}_{s} denoting the s th negative zero of the function \mathrm{Ai}' and q_{0}(\zeta)=t(\zeta).

For the first zero of U\left(a,x\right) we also have u_{a,1}\sim 2^{\frac{1}{2}}\mu\left(1-1.85575\;708\mu^{-4/3}-0.34438\;34\mu^{- 8/3}-0.16871\;5\mu^{-4}-0.11414\mu^{-16/3}-0.0808\mu^{-20/3}-\cdots\right) , where the numerical coefficients have been rounded off.
For further information, including associated functions, see ( ) .

\int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-\frac{1}{4}t^{2}}t^{\mu-1}U\left(a,t\right)\mathrm{d}t= \frac{\sqrt{\pi}2^{-\frac{1}{2}(\mu+a+\frac{1}{2})}\Gamma\left(\mu\right)}{ \Gamma\left(\frac{1}{2}(\mu+a+\frac{3}{2})\right)}, subject to \Re\mu>0 , \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-\frac{3}{4}t^{2}}t^{-a-\frac{3}{2}}U\left(a,t\right) \mathrm{d}t=2^{\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{2}a}\Gamma\left(-a-\tfrac{1}{2}\right)\cos \left((\tfrac{1}{4}a+\tfrac{1}{8})\pi\right), subject to \Re a<-\tfrac{1}{2}, \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-\frac{1}{4}t^{2}}t^{-a-\frac{1}{2}}(x^{2}+t^{2})^{-1}U \left(a,t\right)\mathrm{d}t=\sqrt{\pi/2}\Gamma\left(\tfrac{1}{2}-a\right)x^{-a -\frac{3}{2}}e^{\frac{1}{4}x^{2}}U\left(-a,x\right), subject to \Re a<\tfrac{1}{2},x>0.
When z (=x) is real the left-hand side equals (F(a,x))^{2} ; compare (LABEL:eq:PC.2.18).
For further integrals see §§LABEL:sec:CH.MU.IN, LABEL:sec:CH.KM.IN, and use (LABEL:eq:PC.RO.K3).
See also ( ) and ( ) .

U\left(a,x+y\right)=e^{\frac{1}{2}xy+\frac{1}{4}y^{2}}\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\frac {(-y)^{m}}{m!}U\left(a-m,x\right) , U\left(a,x+y\right)=e^{-\frac{1}{2}xy-\frac{1}{4}y^{2}}\sum_{m=0}^{\infty} \genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{}{-a-\tfrac{1}{2}}{m}y^{m}U\left(a+m,x\right) , V\left(a,x+y\right)=e^{\frac{1}{2}xy+\frac{1}{4}y^{2}}\sum_{m=0}^{\infty} \genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{}{a-\tfrac{1}{2}}{m}y^{m}V\left(a-m,x\right) , V\left(a,x+y\right)=e^{-\frac{1}{2}xy-\frac{1}{4}y^{2}}\sum_{m=0}^{\infty} \frac{y^{m}}{m!}V\left(a+m,x\right).

U\left(a,x\cos t+y\sin t\right)\\ =e^{\frac{1}{4}(x\sin t-y\cos t)^{2}}\*\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt }{}{-a-\tfrac{1}{2}}{m}(\tan t)^{m}U\left(m+a,x\right)U\left(-m-\tfrac{1}{2},y \right), subject to \Re a\leq-\tfrac{1}{2},0\leq t\leq\tfrac{1}{4}\pi.

n!U\left(n+\tfrac{1}{2},z\right)=i^{n}e^{-\frac{1}{2}z^{2}}\operatorname{erfc} (z/\sqrt{2})U\left(-n-\tfrac{1}{2},iz\right)+\sum_{m=1}^{\left\lfloor\frac{1}{ 2}n+\frac{1}{2}\right\rfloor}U\left(2m-n-\tfrac{1}{2},z\right), subject to n=0,1,2,\dots.
For \operatorname{erfc} see §LABEL:sec:ER.DF.ER.
In this section solutions of equation (LABEL:eq:PC.DE.D3) are considered. This equation is important when a and z (=x) are real, and we shall assume this to be the case.
In other cases the general theory of (LABEL:eq:PC.DE.D2) is available.
W\left(a,x\right) and W\left(a,-x\right) form a numerically satisfactory pair of solutions when -\infty<x<\infty.

W\left(a,0\right)=2^{-\frac{3}{4}}\left|\frac{\Gamma\left(\tfrac{1}{4}+\tfrac{ 1}{2}ia\right)}{\Gamma\left(\tfrac{3}{4}+\tfrac{1}{2}ia\right)}\right|^{\frac{ 1}{2}}, W'\left(a,0\right)=-2^{-\frac{1}{4}}\left|\frac{\Gamma\left(\tfrac{3}{4}+ \tfrac{1}{2}ia\right)}{\Gamma\left(\tfrac{1}{4}+\tfrac{1}{2}ia\right)}\right|^ {\frac{1}{2}}.
\mathscr{W}\left\{W\left(a,x\right),W\left(a,-x\right)\right\}=1.
For the modulus functions \widetilde{F}(a,x) and \widetilde{G}(a,x) see §LABEL:sec:PC.EW.MP.

W\left(a,x\right)=\sqrt{k/2}\,e^{\frac{1}{4}\pi a}\left(e^{i\rho}U\left(ia,xe^ {-\pi i/4}\right)+e^{-i\rho}U\left(-ia,xe^{\pi i/4}\right)\right), where k=\sqrt{1+e^{2\pi a}}-e^{\pi a}, 1/k=\sqrt{1+e^{2\pi a}}+e^{\pi a}, \rho=\tfrac{1}{8}\pi+\tfrac{1}{2}\phi_{2}, \phi_{2}=\operatorname{ph}\Gamma\left(\tfrac{1}{2}+ia\right), the branch of \operatorname{ph} being zero when a=0 and defined by continuity elsewhere.
W\left(a,x\right)=W\left(a,0\right)w_{1}(a,x)+W'\left(a,0\right)w_{2}(a,x).

Here w_{1}(a,x) and w_{2}(a,x) are the even and odd solutions of (LABEL:eq:PC.DE.D3): w_{1}(a,x)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\alpha_{n}(a)\frac{x^{2n}}{(2n)!} , w_{2}(a,x)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\beta_{n}(a)\frac{x^{2n+1}}{(2n+1)!} , where \alpha_{n}(a) and \beta_{n}(a) satisfy the recursion relations \alpha_{n+2}=a\alpha_{n+1}-\tfrac{1}{2}(n+1)(2n+1)\alpha_{n}, \beta_{n+2}=a\beta_{n+1}-\tfrac{1}{2}(n+1)(2n+3)\beta_{n}, with \alpha_{0}(a)=1, \alpha_{1}(a)=a, \beta_{0}(a)=1, \beta_{1}(a)=a.

Other expansions, involving \cos\left(\tfrac{1}{4}x^{2}\right) and \sin\left(\tfrac{1}{4}x^{2}\right) , can be obtained from (LABEL:eq:PC.SM.M3) to (LABEL:eq:PC.SM.M6) by replacing a by -ia and z by xe^{\ifrac{\pi i}{4}} ; see ( , p. 80) , and also (LABEL:eq:PC.EW.W12) and (LABEL:eq:PC.EW.W13).
These follow from the contour integrals of §LABEL:sec:PC.IR.CI, which arevalid for general complex values of the argument z and parameter a.

For the notation see §LABEL:sec:BS.DEF.SS. When x>0 W\left(0,\pm x\right)=2^{-\frac{5}{4}}\sqrt{\pi x}\left(J_{-\frac{1}{4}}\left( \tfrac{1}{4}x^{2}\right)\mp J_{\frac{1}{4}}\left(\tfrac{1}{4}x^{2}\right) \right), \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}W\left(0,\pm x\right)=-2^{-\frac{9}{4}}x\sqrt{ \pi x}\left(J_{\frac{3}{4}}\left(\tfrac{1}{4}x^{2}\right)\pm J_{-\frac{3}{4}} \left(\tfrac{1}{4}x^{2}\right)\right).
For the notation see §LABEL:sec:CH.MU.DE.KU.
The even and odd solutions of (LABEL:eq:PC.DE.D3) (see §LABEL:sec:PC.EW.MS) are given by

w_{1}(a,x)=e^{-\frac{1}{4}ix^{2}}M\left(\tfrac{1}{4}-\tfrac{1}{2}ia,\tfrac{1}{ 2},\tfrac{1}{2}ix^{2}\right)=e^{\frac{1}{4}ix^{2}}M\left(\tfrac{1}{4}+\tfrac{1 }{2}ia,\tfrac{1}{2},-\tfrac{1}{2}ix^{2}\right), w_{2}(a,x)=xe^{-\frac{1}{4}ix^{2}}M\left(\tfrac{3}{4}-\tfrac{1}{2}ia,\tfrac{3} {2},\tfrac{1}{2}ix^{2}\right)=xe^{\frac{1}{4}ix^{2}}M\left(\tfrac{3}{4}+\tfrac {1}{2}ia,\tfrac{3}{2},-\tfrac{1}{2}ix^{2}\right).

Write W\left(a,x\right)=\sqrt{\frac{2k}{x}}\left(s_{1}(a,x)\cos\omega-s_{2}(a,x)\sin \omega\right), W\left(a,-x\right)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{kx}}\left(s_{1}(a,x)\sin\omega+s_{2}(a,x) \cos\omega\right), where \omega=\tfrac{1}{4}x^{2}-a\ln x+\tfrac{1}{4}\pi+\tfrac{1}{2}\phi_{2}, with \phi_{2} given by (LABEL:eq:PC.EW.W7).
The coefficients c_{2r} and d_{2r} are obtainable by equating real and imaginary parts in c_{2r}+id_{2r}=\frac{\Gamma\left(2r+\tfrac{1}{2}+ia\right)}{\Gamma\left(\tfrac {1}{2}+ia\right)}.

The main applications of PCFs in mathematical physics arise when solving the Helmholtz equation 
abla^{2}w+k^{2}w=0, where k is a constant, and 
abla^{2} is the Laplacian 
abla^{2}= rac{{\partial}^{2}}{{\partial x}^{2}}+ rac{{\partial}^{2}}{{ \partial y}^{2}}+ rac{{\partial}^{2}}{{\partial z}^{2}} in Cartesian coordinates x,y,z of three-dimensional space (§LABEL:sec:AL.FOT.la).

By using instead coordinates of the parabolic cylinder \xi,\eta,\zeta , defined by x=\xi\eta, y=\tfrac{1}{2}\xi^{2}-\tfrac{1}{2}\eta^{2}, z=\zeta, (LABEL:eq:PC.PA.P1) becomes \frac{1}{\xi^{2}+\eta^{2}}\left(\frac{{\partial}^{2}w}{{\partial\xi}^{2}}+ \frac{{\partial}^{2}w}{{\partial\eta}^{2}}\right)+\frac{{\partial}^{2}w}{{ \partial\zeta}^{2}}+k^{2}w=0.

Setting w=U(\xi)V(\eta)W(\zeta) and separating variables, we obtain \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}U}{{\mathrm{d}\xi}^{2}}+\left(\sigma\xi^{2}+\lambda \right)U=0, \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}V}{{\mathrm{d}\eta}^{2}}+\left(\sigma\eta^{2}-\lambda \right)V=0, \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}W}{{\mathrm{d}\zeta}^{2}}+\left(k^{2}-\sigma\right)W=0, with arbitrary constants \sigma,\lambda.
The first two equations can be transformed into (LABEL:eq:PC.DE.D2) or (LABEL:eq:PC.DE.D3).
In a similar manner coordinates of the paraboloid of revolution transform theHelmholtz equation into equations related to the differential equations considered in this chapter.
